title: 109_hr1862
content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" defines the Secretary as the Secretary of Commerce and professional sports associations as specific leagues. Mandatory drug testing for athletes is required under this Act. The Secretary must issue regulations within 270 days of the Act's enactment, requiring professional sports associations to implement drug testing policies for athletes participating in their leagues. Athletes must be tested at least once a year during their participation in the association's activities. The Secretary will issue regulations for drug testing in professional sports associations. Tests will be conducted randomly throughout the year without prior notification to athletes. A list of prohibited substances will be determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency and the Secretary. Testing will focus on performance-enhancing substances deemed reasonable and practicable. Penalties for positive drug tests in professional sports include a minimum 2-year suspension from participation. Testing must be conducted by an independent party, and penalties are subject to appeal. An athlete who tests positive for drugs, especially if it's not the first time, will face permanent suspension from professional sports, with a loss of pay during the suspension. The athlete's name will be made public. There is an appeals process available for athletes facing penalties for positive drug tests. An athlete who tests positive for drugs has the opportunity for a prompt hearing and a right to appeal. The athlete must file an appeal within 5 days of learning about the positive test. The professional sports association will hold a hearing and make a final decision within 30 days of receiving the appeal. Penalties will be stayed pending the appeal and final decision. The Secretary can exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations for athlete drug testing. SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

After 1 year from the final rules issuance, the Secretary can fine sports associations not following drug testing regulations. The initial fine is $5,000,000 and can increase by $1,000,000 daily for noncompliance.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must provide a report every 2 years on the effectiveness of regulations and compliance by professional sports associations. Additionally, the Comptroller General will conduct a study on college and secondary school testing policies and procedures. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes, focusing on prohibited substance policies and testing procedures of athletic associations, college departments, and secondary schools. A report must be transmitted within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will assess testing policies for performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletics and make recommendations to Congress on expanding regulations to athletic associations.
